thread.title: SAP Profit Lifted by Cloud Subscriptions -- 2nd Update
thread.title_full: SAP Profit Lifted by Cloud Subscriptions -- 2nd Update

author: morningstar.com
title: SAP Profit Lifted by Cloud Subscriptions -- 2nd Update
text:
By Christopher Alessi
FRANKFURT--German business software provider SAP SE on Tuesday said it had posted a 2% rise in net profit for the third quarter, helped by new subscriptions for its Internet cloud-based products.
Net profit for the period ended Sept. 30 was EUR898 million, compared with EUR880 million during the same period last year.
The company also provided a net profit figure of EUR1.17 billion based on calculations that aren't recognized under international financial reporting standards. Analysts had predicted a non-IFRS net profit of EUR1.09 billion for the quarter, according to a recent poll conducted by The Wall Street Journal.
"Clearly the third quarter is a beat," said Chief Executive Bill McDermott, suggesting that the company had a chance to "outrun" its guidance for the full year.
SAP last week reiterated its outlook for fiscal year 2015, saying it expects full-year non-IFRS cloud subscriptions and support revenue to be in a range of EUR1.95 billion to EUR2.05 billion at constant currencies. Full year non-IFRS operating profit should be in a range of EUR5.6 billion to EUR5.9 billion at constant currencies.
SAP pre-released some of its third quarter figures last week, reporting a 5% increase in the company's closely watched operating profit, to EUR1.21 billion. Total revenue rose by 17% to EUR4.98 billion, buoyed by strong growth in the cloud and a solid uptake of new on-premise software licenses. Cloud subscriptions and support revenue increased by over 100% to EUR599 million year-over-year.
Mr. McDermott has moved in recent years to focus the company more squarely on cloud technology, rather than on-premise software. The strategy shift has included a series of acquisitions, including last year's $8.2 billion purchase of U.S.-based cloud expense management software provider, Concur Technologies Inc.
SAP earlier this year launched a redesign of its core Business Suite software, S/4HANA, which operates on the company's real-time, in-memory database--either in the cloud, on hardware or as part of a hybrid solution. SAP said it had more than 1,300 S/4HANA customers at the end of the third quarter.
"The scenario of the future will be hybrid. The world is not binary in that sense," Chief Financial Officer Luka Mucic said in an interview with The Wall Street Journal, referencing the continued importance of on-premise licenses to SAP's business.
SAP's final third quarter results were largely in line with analysts' expectations. Analysts at DZ Bank noted Tuesday that the figures did "not surprise" and that SAP was making progress relative to its cloud competitors.
The results come just months after Mr. McDermott, an American who became sole CEO in 2014, lost his eye after falling down stairs at his brother's house in the U.S. and landing on a water glass he was holding. Mr. McDermott acknowledged today that the accident had kept him in intensive care for a week. But he insisted he was fully and capably back to work and that no emergency succession plans are in place.
Write to Christopher Alessi at christopher.alessi@wsj.com
